PageElement.TextBox:
This lesson will give you an introduction to environmental law and the Resource Management Act 1991 (the 'RMA').
 
You should complete the lesson in about 15 minutes.
 
You will learn:
 
  • What is environmental law?
 
  • What is the purpose of the RMA?
 
  • Why should we take our environmental obligations seriously?
 
  • Who is liable under the RMA?
 
  • What happens if the RMA is breached?
 
The purpose of this generic resource management training program is to alert users to some of the issues which may arise in their industry or area of operations. It does not contain targeted legal advice or a comprehensive tailored resource management compliance programme. You should seek specialist resource management advice on particular issues of concern.
 
To get started, please click on the ► button below.

ABC Limited is constructing a new motorway linking the outer suburbs to the State highway. In the first stage of construction the company contracts a bulldozer to carry out earthworks. The bulldozer breaks down, and an inspection reveals that the fuel has been contaminated. In order to refuel the bulldozer, the driver pumps the fuel into a nearby drain. The driver does not discuss this decision with the site manager.
 
ABC Limited does not hold any consents, permits or licences for these works.
Consider this scenario while reading the next pages...

Environmental law is the general name given for many different laws that protect the environment and regulate the use of natural and physical resources. 
 
The key legislation is the Resource Management Act 1991 ('RMA').
 
The RMA came into force in October 1991 and was a major overhaul of town planning and environmental law.  It is an ‘effects based’ statute, i.e. it focuses on managing the environmental impacts or effects of activities rather than the effects themselves.  This contrasts with the zone based approach of previous Town and Country Planning Acts.  The Act seeks to enable the use, development and protection of resources, and will not intervene unless a proposed or existing activity is likely to cause unacceptable environmental effects.
 
The purpose of the RMA is to promote sustainable management of resources by:
 
  • managing the use, development and protection of resources in a way, or at a rate, which enables people and communities to provide for their social, economic and cultural well being, and for their health and safety
 
  • sustaining the potential of resources to meet the reasonably foreseeable needs of future generations
 
  • safeguarding the life supporting capacity of air, water, soil, and ecosystems
 
  • avoiding, remedying or mitigating any adverse effects of activities on the environment.
 
The 'environment', which the RMA protects, is not simply the natural world. It includes people and communities, amenity values (i.e. the pleasantness or aesthetic coherence of an area), social, economic and cultural matters. It also includes ecosystems and their essential parts, which includes community activities and beliefs.

Page.Title: Why should we take our environmental law obligations seriously?

PageElement.TextBox:
Complying with environmental laws is good business practice and the right thing to do, to protect and preserve the environment for future generations.
 
Non-compliance with the RMA also poses serious legal and financial risks for an organisation and its individuals.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for an example of a case where a company manager has been imprisoned for an environmental offence.
    R v Conway [2005] NZRMA 274
     
    Mr Conway had been managing the operations of a metal scrap yard company on a property in South Auckland. Although it was necessary to obtain resource consent from the Manukau City Council to operate such a scrap yard, no such consent was ever obtained. 
     
    Over a period of time scrap vehicles had been handled in a way which resulted in the discharge of contaminants into the nearby Tamaki Estuary and onto the land itself. No resource consent had been obtained for the discharge of contaminants.
     
    In addition, Mr Conway had instructed an employee to puncture a large number of 200 litre drums containing oil and solvented paint washings. Their contents were discharged onto the ground near the estuary and a complaint was lodged at council.
     
    The council officers, on visiting the site, served abatement notices on Mr Conway and the two companies involved, requiring that the discharge problems be remedied. Subsequent visits revealed that very little was being done to remedy the issues, so enforcement orders were sought from the Environment Court.
     
    The enforcement orders were breached and all three parties pleaded guilty when the matter came before the Court.
     
    A prison sentence of three months was imposed on Mr Conway for his part in the offences.
     
    The Court noted that although the actual harm caused on the environment was moderate, the defendants’ disregard of abatement notices and enforcement orders justified the need for such  firm sentences. In addition, in respect of the imprisonment of Mr Conway, the Court also stressed the need to deter such illegal actions where an offender may believe that they are only undertaking an economic risk.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox: It is not just the company at risk: directors, managers, occupiers, employees and contractors can all be liable for environmental offences. Liability under the RMA is further explained, later in this lesson.

Page.Title: Examples of where resource consents are required

PageElement.TextBox:
Generally, a resource consent will be required for an activity that might have a significant impact on the environment.  For example, the following activities will usually require one or more consents:
 
  • new major projects that are likely to have a significant impact on the environment (e.g. lakes, rivers or harbours)
 
  • discharging substances into water, including soil, sand, dust and cement and wastewater
 
  • discharging substances onto land, including treated wastewater or recycled water
 
  • releasing substances into air, including smoke, dust and odour
 
  • excessive noise, such as noise from industrial equipment or blasting
 
  • clearing land, including removal of individual trees or plants
 
  • exploring for minerals, oil and gas
 
  • constructing and operating mines, quarries and processing plants
 
  • transporting and disposing of industrial waste
 
  • transporting, storing and disposing of hazardous chemicals and substances (e.g. explosive, poisonous or radioactive substances including asbestos)
 
  • disturbing or destroying cultural artefacts, relics and sites of significance to Maori, e.g. ancestral lands or sites of archaeological significance
 
  • constructing, altering or demolishing a building and using land for particular purposes
 
  • disturbing or destroying European heritage.

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for more information on the disposal of contaminated fuel
    Grease, oil, fuel, or other pollutants, should never be put down stormwater drains, as they run into creeks, rivers, beaches, bays and harbours, polluting the water. It is also generally an offence to put pollutants in stormwater drains, or to leave pollutants in a place where they can be washed or blown into drains. 
     
    These actions could be punished with an infringement notice, or might even attract Court prosecution. The public often report suspicious spills and environmental damage to the relevant regional or district council for investigation. Organisations are also often required by their resource consent conditions to analyse drains on or near their sites to identify harmful materials.
     
    The contractor who employs the bulldozer driver or the organisation engaging the contractor should have waste disposal procedures which (depending on the type of waste created on site) would normally include arrangements with licensed waste contractors. The organisation should have ensured it and/or the contractor had a waste disposal procedure in place.  Both the organisation and the contractor should have ensured the bulldozer driver was aware of the waste disposal procedure for the site.

Page.Title: What are the sources of environmental law?

PageElement.TextBox:
Legislation
Legislation (such as the RMA) sets out the primary statutory obligations and what penalties the courts can impose if the legislation is breached.
 
Legislation also lists who has the power to make decisions about environmental matters, such as government ministers and regional or territorial authorities (i.e. district or city councils). These decisions include:
 
  • whether to start legal proceedings to ask a Court to find an organisation guilty of committing an offence and impose a penalty 
  • whether to grant a resource consent.

Resource Consents
Resource consents under the RMA are usually granted subject to conditions. The conditions are legally binding requirements.  If an organisation does not comply with the conditions, it will commit an offence.

Judge-made law (i.e. case law)
The Courts determine a variety of issues including:
 
  • disputes about the meaning of legislation, whether a resource consent should be granted, changes to planning rules, conditions in a consent
  • whether a person has breached any legislation, a contract or a resource consent
  • what penalty or remedy to impose.

Contracts
Contracts are agreements that create legal obligations between the parties to the contract.
They can contain an agreement between two or more parties (e.g. a principal and a contractor) about how they will together comply with the law and manage the environmental risks and liabilities associated with an activity.   For example a contract for sale of land between a seller and a purchaser might specify how, and to what standard, contaminated land must be cleaned up before the title and purchase price are exchanged.

If a party does not comply with a contract, the other party can, in some circumstances, bring an action in the Courts seeking damages, an order requiring performance of the contract or various other remedies.

The RMA applies to any ‘person’ who wishes to use or develop any natural or physical resource to which the RMA relates – i.e. land, coastal marine areas, rivers, water, air.
 
The definition of ‘person’ includes all individuals, companies, organisations, local and regional councils, and any other body of persons whether incorporated or not. It also includes the Crown.
 
The RMA provides that a company will be liable for the actions of its agents, contractors and employees, unless the company can prove that neither the directors nor management knew that the offending activity was being committed, or that the company took all reasonable steps to prevent it from happening. The company must also show that subsequently it took reasonable measures to remedy the effects of the offending act.
 
Where the company is convicted of an offence under the RMA, every director or member of management who either authorised or knew about the offending act (and failed to take reasonable steps to prevent it), is also liable.
 
Directors and employees of the company will remain liable under the RMA, regardless of the liability of the company. They cannot take a passive role in terms of their environmental responsibility, nor be indemnified by the company if prosecuted under the RMA. The regime of the RMA is to encourage individual responsibility. It is no defence to say that 'you were doing what you were told'.
 
Even when an activity is permitted, it must be carried out in such a way as to minimise adverse environmental effects.

Miss Milne is employed by Medi Vans Ltd as a delivery driver. During a delivery run, she forgets to lock the medical waste and chemicals she is transporting into place inside the van. Upon hearing the containers fall out and smash in the back, Miss Milne stops the vehicle. The containers are leaking all over the inside of the van floor and to prevent damage to the company vehicle she pulls the broken, leaking containers out onto the side of the road.
 
The chemicals and waste flow into the stormwater drain and cause substantial pollution.
 
Subsequently, both Miss Milne and Medi Vans Ltd are prosecuted under the RMA.

PageElement.MultiChoiceQA:
Does Medi Vans Ltd staff training programme, which outlines what to do in the instance of a spill offsite, provide a defence to the alleged breach of the RMA?
 
No, the company is always liable for the actions of its employees.
That is incorrect.
 
Although companies are liable under the RMA for the actions of their employees, contractors or agents, it is a defence to show that the company took reasonable steps to prevent the offence happening. Evidence of a comprehensive staff training programme may provide a basis for a successful defence. It is also a defence if the company can show that neither directors nor management knew (or should have known) that the offence was or could be committed.
Yes, it is a defence for a company to show that it took reasonable steps to deal with foreseeable incidents.

PageElement.TextBox:
As a general rule, an activity will be in breach of the RMA if it is not permitted by:
 
  • a rule in an applicable district or regional plan
  • a resource consent
  • ‘existing use’ rights

PageElement.ExtraInfo:
• Click here for information on existing use rights
    Existing use rights apply in some circumstances where an activity has been lawfully established before rules controlling that activity came into force.  Where it has been lawfully established, and the activity remains of the same ‘character, intensity and scale’, it will be protected against enforcement action (even if a rule is later included in the district plan which controls or prohibits it.)
     
    For example, Gillian runs a wedding function centre and has done for the past ten years. At a later date the new local council changes its district plan, resulting in Gillian’s land being rezoned as residential. Gillian will be able to claim an ‘existing use’ right and is permitted to continue to run wedding functions on the site despite the zone change.
     
    However, if Gillian decides to open the function centre up to the public as a restaurant and bar (increasing the scale and intensity of her business) such activity will be subject to the new regime and is likely to fall outside her existing use rights.
    [Hide]

PageElement.TextBox:
District /Regional plans and resource consents are considered in more detail in the next two lessons of this course.
 
There are four principal enforcement mechanisms under the RMA:
 
  • infringement notices (instant fines for low level offences)
  • abatement notices (a notice issued by the Council requiring a person to stop an activity or take steps to remedy adverse effects on the environment)
  • enforcement orders (an order of the Environment Court requiring a person to stop an activity or take steps to remedy the situation - these act in a similar way to injunctions)
  • prosecutions.
 
The maximum penalties under the RMA have been modified by recent legislative reform and for serious breaches by an individual may amount to $300,000 in fines or up to two years in prison. In the instance of a company or business committing the offence the penalty may be up to $600,000. In either case if the offence is a continuing one, a fine of $10,000 per day for each further day may apply.
